Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in at least one programming language, which is a quantifiable skill that can be developed with practice.
Title: COMPUTATIONAL GENOMICS
Description: Prerequisites: Working knowledge of at least one programming language, and some background in probability and statistics. Computational techniques for analyzing genomic data including DNA, RNA, protein and gene expression data. Basic concepts in molecular biology relevant to these analyses. Emphasis on techniques from artificial intelligence and machine learning. String-matching algorithms, dynamic programming, hidden Markov models, expectation-maximization, neural networks, clustering algorithms, support vector machines. Students with life sciences backgrounds who satisfy the prerequisites are encouraged to enroll.

Title: Topics in Database System
Description:
The course "Topics in Database Systems" at Columbia University is a graduate-level class that focuses on the research and design of database internals and systems design
1
. The course is not offered during the 2023-2024 academic year
5
. The main goal of the course is to provide students with a deeper understanding of advanced database concepts and the latest trends in both database research and industry
5
.
The course builds upon the knowledge gained in the prerequisite course "Introduction to Databases" (COMS W4111)
4
. Students are expected to have a strong foundation in database design and application development using databases, including entity-relationship modeling, logical design of relational databases, and relational data definition and manipulation
4
.
Course Content
The course covers a range of topics related to database systems, including:
Database internals: Students will learn about the internal workings of database systems, including storage management, query processing, and transaction management
1
.
Systems design: The course will explore various design principles and techniques for building efficient and scalable database systems
1
.
Advanced database concepts: Students will study advanced topics such as distributed databases, parallel databases, and data stream processing
1
.
Latest trends in database research and industry: The course will cover recent developments in the field, including new database models, NoSQL databases, and big data processing
1
.
Projects
The course includes programming projects that allow students to apply the concepts and techniques learned in class. The projects are implemented in Python
5
.
Learning Outcomes
By the end of the course, students should have:
A deeper understanding of database internals and systems design
1
.
Knowledge of advanced database concepts and the latest trends in the field
5
.
The ability to design and implement efficient and scalable database systems
1
.
Experience working on real-world database projects
5
.

Explanation: Students will implement programming projects in Python, developing their ability to handle and manipulate data using this language.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design user-friendly interfaces for computer systems, websites, and mobile applications.
Title: Human-Computer Interactio
Description: Human–computer interaction (HCI) studies (1) what computers are used for, (2) how people interact with computers, and (3) how either of those should change in the future. Topics include ubiquitous computing, mobile health, interaction techniques, social computing, mixed reality, accessibility, and ethics. Activities include readings, presentations, and discussions of research papers. Substantial HCI research project required.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design user-friendly interfaces for computer systems, websites, and mobile applications.

Topics include ubiquitous computing, mobile health, interaction techniques, social computing, mixed reality, accessibility, and ethics. Activities include readings, presentations, and discussions of research papers. Substantial HCI research project required.

Explanation: Students will develop the skill of creating interactive prototypes to visualize and test design concepts before implementation.

Title: TECH WRITING FOR CS AND E
Description: Prerequisites: Available to M.S. and Ph.D candidates in CS/CE. Topics to help CS/CE graduate students’ communication skills. Explanation: Students will develop the ability to present information in a clear and concise manner.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in Java programming, which is essential for working with data structures in Java.
Title: DATA STRUCTURES IN JAVA
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W1004) or knowledge of Java. Data types and structures: arrays, stacks, singly and doubly linked lists, queues, trees, sets, and graphs. Programming techniques for processing such structures: sorting and searching, hashing, garbage collection. Storage management. Rudiments of the analysis of algorithms. Taught in Java. Note: Due to significant overlap, students may receive credit for only one of the following three courses: COMS W3134, COMS W3136, COMS W3137.

Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W1004) or (COMS W1007) Corequisites: COMS W3203 An honors introduction to data types and structures: arrays, stacks, singly and doubly linked lists, queues, trees, sets, and graphs. Programming techniques for processing such structures: sorting and searching, hashing, garbage collection. Storage management. Design and analysis of algorithms. Taught in Java. Note: Due to significant overlap, students may receive credit for only one of the following three courses: COMS W3134, W3136, or W3137.

Explanation: Students will develop the skill of performing computations involving matrices and vectors, which is a fundamental skill in linear algebra.
Title: COMPUTATIONAL LINEAR ALGE
Description:
The course "COMS 3251: Computational Linear Algebra" at Columbia University is an introduction to linear algebra and its applications in computational settings
1
. The course covers various topics, including matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, canonical forms, and applications
2
. The primary objectives of the course are to teach students how to use linear algebra as a powerful tool for computation and to develop their ability to write mathematical proofs
6
.
The course is designed for students who have already taken MATH UN1201 Calculus III or its equivalent, although it is strongly recommended for students to have a background in calculus
2
. The textbook used for the course is "Linear Algebra with Applications, 5th edition" by Otto Bretscher
2
.
The course syllabus provides a detailed outline of the topics covered in the course
3
. Here is a summary of the main topics:
Linear Equations:
Introduction to Linear Systems
Matrices, Vectors, and Gauss-Jordan Elimination
Solutions of Linear Systems; Matrix Algebra
Linear Transformations:
Introduction to Linear Transformations and Their Inverses
Linear Transformations in Geometry
Matrix Products
The Inverse of a Linear Transformation
Subspaces of Rn and Their Dimensions
Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors:
Introduction to Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
Diagonalization
Applications of Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
Orthogonality and Least Squares:
Inner Products and Orthogonal Vectors
Orthogonal Projections and the Gram-Schmidt Process
Least Squares Approximations
Determinants:
Introduction to Determinants
Properties of Determinants
Cramer's Rule and Volume
Canonical Forms:
Introduction to Canonical Forms
Jordan Canonical Form
Applications of Linear Algebra:
Markov Chains
Linear Programming
Computer Graphics
The course also includes programming assignments and projects that allow students to apply the concepts and techniques learned in class to real-world problems
1
. Students will gain the following skills, knowledge, and abilities through this course:
Understanding of fundamental concepts in linear algebra, such as matrices, vector spaces, and linear transformations
Ability to perform computations involving matrices and vectors
Familiarity with various applications of linear algebra in fields such as computer science, engineering, and economics
Proficiency in writing mathematical proofs
Experience in using programming languages and software tools for solving computational problems in linear algebra
1
5

Explanation: Students will learn how to handle and manipulate deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, which are essential concepts in computer science theory.
Title: COMPUTER SCIENCE THEORY
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3203) Corequisites: COMS W3134,COMS W3136,COMS W3137 Regular languages: deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, regular expressions. Context-free languages: context-free grammars, push-down automata. Turing machines, the Chomsky hierarchy, and the Church-Turing thesis. Introduction to Complexity Theory and NP-Completeness.

Explanation: Students will learn how to handle and manipulate deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, which are essential concepts in computer science theory.
Title: COMPUTER SCIENCE THEORY
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3203) Corequisites: COMS W3134,COMS W3136,COMS W3137 Regular languages: deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, regular expressions. Context-free languages: context-free grammars, push-down automata. Turing machines, the Chomsky hierarchy, and the Church-Turing thesis. Introduction to Complexity Theory and NP-Completeness.

Explanation: Students will learn how to handle and manipulate deterministic and non-deterministic finite automata, which are essential concepts in computer science theory.

Context-free languages: context-free grammars, push-down automata. Turing machines, the Chomsky hierarchy, and the Church-Turing thesis. Introduction to Complexity Theory and NP-Completeness.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in using regular expressions, a powerful tool for pattern matching and text manipulation.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in SQL, which is a fundamental skill in working with databases and querying data.
Title: INTRODUCTION TO DATABASES
Professor: Donald F Ferguson, Kenneth A Ross
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134) or (COMS W3137) or (COMS W3136) and fluency in Java); or the instructor's permission. The fundamentals of database design and application development using databases: entity-relationship modeling, logical design of relational databases, relational data definition and manipulation languages, SQL, XML, query processing, physical database tuning, transaction processing, security. Programming projects are required.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in SQL, which is a fundamental skill in working with databases and querying data.

Explanation: Students will learn about XML (eXtensible Markup Language) and its use in databases, allowing them to work with XML data and integrate it into database systems.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in multiple programming languages, including imperative, object-oriented, declarative, functional, and scripting languages. This skill is selected because the course focuses on teaching different programming languages and their syntax.
Title: PROGRAMMING LANG & TRANSL
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) and (COMS W3261) and (CSEE W3827) or equivalent, or the instructors permission. Modern programming languages and compiler design. Imperative, object-oriented, declarative, functional, and scripting languages. Language syntax, control structures, data types, procedures and parameters, binding, scope, run-time organization, and exception handling. Implementation of language translation tools including compilers and interpreters. Lexical, syntactic and semantic analysis; code generation; introduction to code optimization. Teams implement a language and its compiler.

Explanation: Students will learn about the design and implementation of language translation tools, including compilers and interpreters. This skill is selected because the course covers the implementation of language translation tools and code generation.

Explanation: Students will learn how to handle and manipulate processes in an operating system to accomplish specific objectives.
Title: OPERATING SYSTEMS I
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) and knowledge of C and programming tools as covered in COMS W3136, W3157, or W3101, or the instructors permission. Design and implementation of operating systems. Topics include process management, process synchronization and interprocess communication, memory management, virtual memory, interrupt handling, processor scheduling, device management, I/O, and file systems. Case study of the UNIX operating system. A programming project is required.

Explanation: Students will learn how to handle and manipulate processes in an operating system to accomplish specific objectives.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in managing memory in an operating system, including allocation and deallocation.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design and develop 3D user interfaces, including interaction techniques, metaphors, and dialogue design.
Title: 3D UI AND AUGMENTED REALI
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W4160) or (COMS W4170) or the instructors permission. Design, development, and evaluation of 3D user interfaces. Interaction techniques and metaphors, from desktop to immersive. Selection and manipulation. Travel and navigation. Symbolic, menu, gestural, and multimodal interaction. Dialogue design. 3D software support. 3D interaction devices and displays. Virtual and augmented reality. Tangible user interfaces. Review of relevant 3D math.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in selecting and manipulating objects in a 3D environment.

Description: Advanced security. Centralized, distributed, and cloud system security. Cryptographic protocol design choices. Hardware and software security techniques. Security testing and fuzzing. Blockchain. Human security issues. Note: May not earn credit for both W4182 and W4180 or W4187.

Description: Advanced security. Centralized, distributed, and cloud system security. Cryptographic protocol design choices. Hardware and software security techniques. Security testing and fuzzing. Blockchain. Human security issues. Note: May not earn credit for both W4182 and W4180 or W4187.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design algorithms to solve complex problems efficiently.
Title: Advanced Algorithms
Description: Introduces classic and modern algorithmic ideas that are central to many areas of Computer Science. The focus is on most powerful paradigms and techniques of how to design algorithms, and how to measure their efficiency. The intent is to be broad, covering a diversity of algorithmic techniques, rather than be deep. The covered topics have all been implemented and are widely used in industry. Topics include: hashing, sketching/streaming, nearest neighbor search, graph algorithms, spectral graph theory, linear programming, models for large-scale computation, and other related topics

Explanation: Students will learn how to design algorithms to solve complex problems efficiently.

Explanation: Students will develop the skill of problem-solving as they analyze and solve computational problems.
Title: INTRO-COMPUTATIONAL COMPL
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3261) Develops a quantitative theory of the computational difficulty of problems in terms of the resources (e.g. time, space) needed to solve them. Classification of problems into complexity classes, reductions, and completeness. Power and limitations of different modes of computation such as nondeterminism, randomization, interaction, and parallelism.

Explanation: Students will develop the skill of problem-solving as they analyze and solve computational problems.
Title: INTRO-COMPUTATIONAL COMPL
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3261) Develops a quantitative theory of the computational difficulty of problems in terms of the resources (e.g. time, space) needed to solve them. Classification of problems into complexity classes, reductions, and completeness. Power and limitations of different modes of computation such as nondeterminism, randomization, interaction, and parallelism.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in programming languages and learn how to write efficient and effective code.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design innovative business models to create and grow a technology venture.
Title: PRIN-INNOVATN/ENTREPRENEU
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) or the instructor's permission. Team project centered course focused on principles of planning, creating, and growing a technology venture. Topics include: identifying and analyzing opportunities created by technology paradigm shifts, designing innovative products, protecting intellectual property, engineering innovative business models.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in designing innovative products that align with technology paradigm shifts.
Title: PRIN-INNOVATN/ENTREPRENEU
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) or the instructor's permission. Team project centered course focused on principles of planning, creating, and growing a technology venture. Topics include: identifying and analyzing opportunities created by technology paradigm shifts, designing innovative products, protecting intellectual property, engineering innovative business models.

Explanation: Students will learn strategies for protecting intellectual property in the context of a technology venture.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in Python programming, which is recommended prior knowledge for the course.
Title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) and any course on probability. Prior knowledge of Python is recommended. Provides a broad understanding of the basic techniques for building intelligent computer systems. Topics include state-space problem representations, problem reduction and and-or graphs, game playing and heuristic search, predicate calculus, and resolution theorem proving, AI systems and languages for knowledge representation, machine learning and concept formation and other topics such as natural language processing may be included as time permits.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in Python programming, which is recommended prior knowledge for the course.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in Python programming, which is recommended prior knowledge for the course.

Title: NATURAL LANGUAGE PROCESSI
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) or the instructors permission. Computational approaches to natural language generation and understanding. Recommended preparation: some previous or concurrent exposure to AI or Machine Learning. Topics include information extraction, summarization, machine translation, dialogue systems, and emotional speech. Particular attention is given to robust techniques that can handle understanding and generation for the large amounts of text on the Web or in other large corpora. Programming exercises in several of these areas.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in computational approaches to natural language generation and understanding.

Explanation: Students will learn how to translate text from one language to another using NLP methods.

Title: MACHINE LEARNING FOR DATA
Description:
The course "Machine Learning for Data" is a graduate-level introduction to machine learning offered by Columbia University. The course focuses on a hands-on approach to machine learning and data science, covering basic statistical principles of supervised machine learning and common algorithmic paradigms
1
. The course is part of the Machine Learning Track, which is intended for students who wish to develop their knowledge of machine learning techniques and applications
3
.
The course covers the following topics:
Fundamentals of probability theory and statistical inference used in data science
Probabilistic models, random variables, useful distributions, expectations, law of large numbers, central limit theorem
Statistical inference, point and confidence interval estimation, hypothesis tests, linear regression
Introduction to statistical modeling, maximum likelihood estimates, hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio test, Bayesian inference, etc.
1
Students are expected to have a basic knowledge of programming, calculus, and linear algebra. The course provides a foundation of basic theory and methodology with applied examples to analyze data
1
.
In addition to the theoretical concepts, students will also learn practical skills such as:
Importing, exporting, manipulating, transforming, and visualizing data
Using statistical summaries
Running and evaluating machine learning models
2
4
The course features real-world applications of data analytics across industries and challenges students to think critically and creatively
2
. Students will gain familiarity with machine learning algorithms and applications, as well as a solid foundation in statistics/mathematics and problem-solving skills to help them solve enterprise-level problems
5
.

Explanation: Students will learn how to import, export, manipulate, transform, and visualize data.

Probabilistic models, random variables, useful distributions, expectations, law of large numbers, central limit theorem
Statistical inference, point and confidence interval estimation, hypothesis tests, linear regression
Introduction to statistical modeling, maximum likelihood estimates, hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio test, Bayesian inference, etc.

Title: VISUAL INTERFACES TO COMP
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136 or COMS W3137) Visual input as data and for control of computer systems. Survey and analysis of architecture, algorithms, and underlying assumptions of commercial and research systems that recognize and interpret human gestures, analyze imagery such as fingerprint or iris patterns, generate natural language descriptions of medical or map imagery. Explores foundations in human psychophysics, cognitive science, and artificial intelligence.

Explanation: Students will learn how to analyze and interpret visual input as data.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in designing algorithms for visual recognition and interpretation.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in using MATLAB for implementing machine learning algorithms.
Title: MACHINE LEARNING
Description: Prerequisites: Any introductory course in linear algebra and any introductory course in statistics are both required. Highly recommended: COMS W4701 or knowledge of Artificial Intelligence. Topics from generative and discriminative machine learning including least squares methods, support vector machines, kernel methods, neural networks, Gaussian distributions, linear classification, linear regression, maximum likelihood, exponential family distributions, Bayesian networks, Bayesian inference, mixture models, the EM algorithm, graphical models and hidden Markov models. Algorithms implemented in MATLAB.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in using MATLAB for implementing machine learning algorithms.

Description: Prerequisites: Any introductory course in linear algebra and any introductory course in statistics are both required. Highly recommended: COMS W4701 or knowledge of Artificial Intelligence. Topics from generative and discriminative machine learning including least squares methods, support vector machines, kernel methods, neural networks, Gaussian distributions, linear classification, linear regression, maximum likelihood, exponential family distributions, Bayesian networks, Bayesian inference, mixture models, the EM algorithm, graphical models and hidden Markov models. Algorithms implemented in MATLAB.

Explanation: Students will learn the skills required to design and develop system-on-chip (SoC) architectures.
Title: EMBEDDED SCALABLE PLATFOR
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4868) or the instructor permission. Inter-disciplinary graduate-level seminar on design and programming of embedded scalable platforms. Content varies between offerings to cover timely relevant issues and latest advances in system-on-chip design, embedded software programming, and electronic design automation. Requires substantial reading of research papers, class participation, and semester-long project.

Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4868) or the instructor permission. Inter-disciplinary graduate-level seminar on design and programming of embedded scalable platforms. Content varies between offerings to cover timely relevant issues and latest advances in system-on-chip design, embedded software programming, and electronic design automation. Requires substantial reading of research papers, class participation, and semester-long project.

Explanation: Students will develop the skill of reading and analyzing research papers related to embedded scalable platforms.
Title: EMBEDDED SCALABLE PLATFOR

Requires substantial reading of research papers, class participation, and semester-long project.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design and manipulate digital circuits using Boolean algebra, Karnaugh maps, and basic gates.
Title: FUNDAMENTALS OF COMPUTER
Description: Prerequisites: an introductory programming course. Fundamentals of computer organization and digital logic. Boolean algebra, Karnaugh maps, basic gates and components, flipflops and latches, counters and state machines, basics of combinational and sequential digital design. Assembly language, instruction sets, ALU’s, single-cycle and multi-cycle processor design, introduction to pipelined processors, caches, and virtual memory.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design and manipulate digital circuits using Boolean algebra, Karnaugh maps, and basic gates.

Explanation: Students will develop programming skills in Python, C++, Java, or Ruby, which are essential for working with computer networks.
Title: COMPUTER NETWORKS
Description: Prerequisites: Comfort with basic probability. Programming fluency in Python, C++, Java, or Ruby (please see section course page for specific language requirements).  Introduction to computer networks and the technical foundations of the Internet, including applications, protocols, local area networks, algorithms for routing and congestion control, security, elementary performance evaluation. Several written and programming assignments required.

Explanation: Students will develop programming skills in Python, C++, Java, or Ruby, which are essential for working with computer networks.

Explanation: Students will learn how to diagnose and resolve network issues, developing the skill of troubleshooting.

Several written and programming assignments required.

Explanation: Students will develop programming skills in Python, C++, Java, or Ruby, which are essential for working with computer networks.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in programming languages and techniques used in computer systems.
Title: COMPUTER SYSTEMS FOR DATA
Description: An introduction to computer architecture and distributed systems with an emphasis on warehouse scale computing systems. Topics will include fundamental tradeoffs in computer systems, hardware and software techniques for exploiting instruction-level parallelism, data-level parallelism and task level parallelism, scheduling, caching, prefetching, network and memory architecture, latency and throughput optimizations, specialization, and an introduction to programming data center computers.

Explanation: Students will learn about hardware and software techniques for exploiting instruction-level parallelism, data-level parallelism, and task level parallelism.
Title: COMPUTER SYSTEMS FOR DATA
Description: An introduction to computer architecture and distributed systems with an emphasis on warehouse scale computing systems. Topics will include fundamental tradeoffs in computer systems, hardware and software techniques for exploiting instruction-level parallelism, data-level parallelism and task level parallelism, scheduling, caching, prefetching, network and memory architecture, latency and throughput optimizations, specialization, and an introduction to programming data center computers.

Explanation: Students will develop skills in understanding and designing network architectures for computer systems.

Explanation: Students will learn techniques for optimizing latency and throughput in computer systems.

Explanation: Students will gain knowledge and skills in specialized areas of computer systems, such as data center computers.
Title: COMPUTER SYSTEMS FOR DATA
Description: An introduction to computer architecture and distributed systems with an emphasis on warehouse scale computing systems. Topics will include fundamental tradeoffs in computer systems, hardware and software techniques for exploiting instruction-level parallelism, data-level parallelism and task level parallelism, scheduling, caching, prefetching, network and memory architecture, latency and throughput optimizations, specialization, and an introduction to programming data center computers.

Explanation: Students will learn how to analyze and interpret data in the context of computer architecture.
Title: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) or equivalent. Focuses on advanced topics in computer architecture, illustrated by case studies from classic and modern processors. Fundamentals of quantitative analysis. Pipelining. Memory hierarchy design. Instruction-level and thread-level parallelism. Data-level parallelism and graphics processing units. Multiprocessors. Cache coherence. Interconnection networks. Multi-core processors and systems-on-chip. Platform architectures for embedded, mobile, and cloud computing.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in understanding and implementing pipelining techniques in computer architecture.
Title: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) or equivalent. Focuses on advanced topics in computer architecture, illustrated by case studies from classic and modern processors. Fundamentals of quantitative analysis. Pipelining. Memory hierarchy design. Instruction-level and thread-level parallelism. Data-level parallelism and graphics processing units. Multiprocessors. Cache coherence. Interconnection networks. Multi-core processors and systems-on-chip. Platform architectures for embedded, mobile, and cloud computing.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design and optimize memory hierarchies in computer systems.
Title: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) or equivalent. Focuses on advanced topics in computer architecture, illustrated by case studies from classic and modern processors. Fundamentals of quantitative analysis. Pipelining. Memory hierarchy design. Instruction-level and thread-level parallelism. Data-level parallelism and graphics processing units. Multiprocessors. Cache coherence. Interconnection networks. Multi-core processors and systems-on-chip. Platform architectures for embedded, mobile, and cloud computing.

Explanation: Students will develop skills in identifying and exploiting different forms of parallelism, such as instruction-level, thread-level, and data-level parallelism.
Title: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) or equivalent. Focuses on advanced topics in computer architecture, illustrated by case studies from classic and modern processors. Fundamentals of quantitative analysis. Pipelining. Memory hierarchy design. Instruction-level and thread-level parallelism. Data-level parallelism and graphics processing units. Multiprocessors. Cache coherence. Interconnection networks. Multi-core processors and systems-on-chip. Platform architectures for embedded, mobile, and cloud computing.

Explanation: Students will learn about cache coherence protocols and techniques used to ensure data consistency in multiprocessor systems.
Title: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W3827) or equivalent. Focuses on advanced topics in computer architecture, illustrated by case studies from classic and modern processors. Fundamentals of quantitative analysis. Pipelining. Memory hierarchy design. Instruction-level and thread-level parallelism. Data-level parallelism and graphics processing units. Multiprocessors. Cache coherence. Interconnection networks. Multi-core processors and systems-on-chip. Platform architectures for embedded, mobile, and cloud computing.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design embedded systems, combining hardware and software, to accomplish specific objectives.
Title: EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4823) Embedded system design and implementation combining hardware and software. I/O, interfacing, and peripherals. Weekly laboratory sessions and term project on design of a microprocessor-based embedded system including at least one custom peripheral. Knowledge of C programming and digital logic required.

Explanation: Students will gain proficiency in C programming, which is essential for developing embedded systems.
Title: EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4823) Embedded system design and implementation combining hardware and software. I/O, interfacing, and peripherals. Weekly laboratory sessions and term project on design of a microprocessor-based embedded system including at least one custom peripheral. Knowledge of C programming and digital logic required.

Explanation: Students will learn how to interface input/output devices with embedded systems, allowing them to manipulate and control external devices.
Title: EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4823) Embedded system design and implementation combining hardware and software. I/O, interfacing, and peripherals. Weekly laboratory sessions and term project on design of a microprocessor-based embedded system including at least one custom peripheral. Knowledge of C programming and digital logic required.

Explanation: Students will acquire knowledge and skills in working with various peripherals, such as sensors, actuators, and communication modules, to enhance the functionality of embedded systems.
Title: EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
Description: Prerequisites: (CSEE W4823) Embedded system design and implementation combining hardware and software. I/O, interfacing, and peripherals. Weekly laboratory sessions and term project on design of a microprocessor-based embedded system including at least one custom peripheral. Knowledge of C programming and digital logic required.

Explanation: Students will learn how to design and implement embedded systems using microprocessors, enabling them to create complex and efficient systems.
Title: EMBEDDED SYSTEMS

Weekly laboratory sessions and term project on design of a microprocessor-based embedded system including at least one custom peripheral. Knowledge of C programming and digital logic required.

Explanation: Students will learn how to analyze the efficiency and performance of algorithms.
Title: ANALYSIS OF ALGORITHMS I
Description: Prerequisites: (COMS W3134 or COMS W3136COMS W3137) and (COMS W3203) Introduction to the design and analysis of efficient algorithms. Topics include models of computation, efficient sorting and searching, algorithms for algebraic problems, graph algorithms, dynamic programming, probabilistic methods, approximation algorithms, and NP-completeness.

Explanation: Students will learn how to analyze the efficiency and performance of algorithms.

Title: INTRO TO COMP FOR ENG/APP
